author: M K
text:
Non-motorised transport is one of the main components of the Smart City proposal.

According to the proposal submitted by the Corporation for the Smart City project, there will be a 30-km non-motorised transport corridor with dedicated biking and pedestrian paths. The city already has 42 per cent public transport and six model roads are under development, said the report.

In all upcoming new road development works in the city, the Corporation will give priority for pedestrians, says Mayor P. Rajkumar.

“We are also conducting a study on the extent of encroachment on footpaths by roadside vendors, extension of shops on footpaths and vehicle parking as they are the main violations that are forcing pedestrians to walk on the road,” he said and added that the Corporation had taken the issue seriously and was planning to evict soon them, with the help of the police.

About the existing projects for the benefit of pedestrians, Mr. Rajkumar said that more than 50 per cent of the construction of the foot overbridge at Saibaba Colony had been completed. The civic body had also proposed to construct three foot overbridges – one each at Ganapathy, Hope College and on Avanashi Road near the airport at an estimate Rs. 50 lakh to Rs. 60 lakh per bridge. “At Lanka Corner, the Corporation in holding talks with the Highways Department to come out with a solution for the safety and convenience of patients and passengers,” the Mayor added.
title: Corporation to focus on footpaths
